title: A Short Review on Synthetic Advances toward the Synthesis of Rufinamide, an Antiepileptic Drug

reactions.text: The medicinal chemistry route to rufinamide was first developed by Ciba-Geigy Corporation in the United States, which after the merger with Sandoz became known as Novartis Corporation. The first synthesis of rufinamide, which was described in U.S. Patent 4,789,680, starts with the reaction of 2,6-difluorobenzyl bromide (1) with sodium azide in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as the solvent at room temperature for 2 h to obtain 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide (2) (Scheme 1), which further undergoes the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction with propiolic acid (3) at 70 °C for several hours in toluene as the solvent to afford 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylic acid (4). The choice of propiolic acid as the dipolarophile is based on its low toxicity and its high reactivity due to the higher electronic deficiency. Furthermore, reacting compound 4 with SOCl2 and distilling out the excess SOCl2 gives 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carbonyl chloride (5), which subsequently reacts with aqueous ammonia in toluene solution to produce rufinamide (7). The patent described another process in which 4 is reacted with methanol in the presence of H2SO4 to get methyl 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylate (6) in good yield, which further reacts with methanolic ammonia solution to afford rufinamide 7 in moderate yield. The 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction of 2 with 3 was carried out on a 36 g scale. The moderate yield of 7 could be attributed to the formation of a mixture of the 1,4- and 1,5-regioisomeric cycloadducts.

In 1998, a further patent application WO1998002423 A1 related to the synthesis of rufinamide was published by the same innovator company to improve the yield and streamline the process using a different dipolarophile. 2-Chloroacrylonitrile (8) is used as a dipolarophile, which is reacted with 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2 for 24 h using H2O as the solvent to obtain intermediate 9 (Scheme 2).

The yield of 9 varied depending upon the reaction temperature, time, and amount of 8. The best conditions, which gave a 98% yield of intermediate 9, were obtained using 1.5 equiv of 8 at 80 °C for 24 h on a 34 g scale. The use of higher amounts of 8 or solvents like heptane, ethanol, toluene, and N,N-dimethylformamide did not increase the yield. Furthermore, the excess 8 was distilled out from the reaction mixture, followed by the hydrolysis of intermediate 9 with NaOH in the presence of toluene as a solvent to obtain rufinamide 7 in good yield.

In 2010, Kankan et al. of Cipla Limited identified the synthesis of rufinamide on a 5 g scale using methyl propiolate (10) as the dipolarophile in U.S. Patent 8,183,269 (Scheme 3). The one-pot synthetic procedure involved the SN2 reaction of 2,6-difluorobenzyl halide 1 with NaN3 in water at 70 °C for 30 h to afford 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2, which further underwent a 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction with 10 to give methyl 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylate (11) at 60 °C for 3–4 h. Without isolation of intermediate 11, 25% aqueous NH3 solution was added to the same reaction mixture dropwise, and the reaction mixture was heated at 75 °C for 4–5 h to obtain rufinamide 7 in 60% yield. However, on applying the multistep synthetic sequence, the yield of rufinamide was dramatically reduced to 36% as calculated over three steps. It is to be noted that apart from toxicity and regioselectivity issues, the high cost of methyl propiolate as a dipolarophile is an obstacle for the large-scale production cycle.

In 2014, Laboratorios Lesvi S.L. demonstrated an improved method for the preparation of the compound 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylic acid (4) that is substantially free from its 1,5-regioisomer (Scheme 6) on a 10 g scale. The synthetic methodology was described in U.S. Patent 8,884,026. The invention disclosed the further use of intermediate 4 for the preparation of rufinamide and the new polymorphic form of rufinamide, known as Form R-5. The new polymorph of rufinamide showed good stability along with appropriate physicochemical properties for its synthesis on the industrial scale. Polymorph Form R-5 will be appropriate for the treatment of epilepsy. 2,6-Difluorobenzyl bromide 1 was reacted with sodium azide and TBAB using isopropyl acetate as the solvent at room temperature for 14 h to obtain the 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2, which further underwent the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction with propiolic acid 3 at 50 °C for 8 h. Upon completion of the reaction and aqueous workup, 4 was obtained in 57% yield along with 99.94% UPLC purity. Subsequently, intermediate 4 was reacted with oxalyl chloride at 0–5 °C under a N2 atmosphere using anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF) as the solvent for 2 h. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was treated with 25% aqueous NH3 and NH4Cl in water at 0–5 °C for 2 h to obtain Form R-5 in 68% yield as only the 1,4-regioisomer.

Compound 15 reacted with 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2 prepared from 2,6-difluorobenzyl halide 1 with NaN3 in water at 75–80 °C for 24 h to obtain alkyl 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylate 11. Further hydrolysis of intermediate 11 with aqueous NaOH at room temperature and refluxing with SOCl2 for 2 h followed by reaction with aqueous ammonia at room temperature afforded rufinamide 7 in excellent yield. The invention also highlights the synthesis of alkyl 2-bromoacrylate 15 in the presence of a brominating reagent followed by treatment with base.

Prompted by this observation, methyl 3-methoxyacrylate (16) was chosen as the dipolarophile, and it reacted with 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2 to afford methyl 1-(2,6-difluorobenzyl)-1H-1,2,3-triazole-4-carboxylate 11 (Scheme 8). Interestingly, the use of 3-methoxyacrylonitrile as the dipolarophile in 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition resulted in the generation of two regioisomers.

The azide–enol ether cycloaddition reaction was carried out under solventless conditions at 135 °C for 28 h to obtain intermediate 11 in 85% yield. Subsequently, ammonolysis of ester 11 proceeded smoothly in 7 M methanolic NH3 solution at room temperature for 18 h to give rufinamide 7 in 79% overall yield. Furthermore, it was observed that the most of the waste was generated during the second step, the ammonolysis of intermediate 11.

Subsequently, ammonolysis of ester 11 proceeded smoothly in 7 M methanolic NH3 solution at room temperature for 18 h to give rufinamide 7 in 79% overall yield. Furthermore, it was observed that the most of the waste was generated during the second step, the ammonolysis of intermediate 11.

In order to avoid the waste generation, the ammonolysis reaction was tried with a reduced volume of methanolic ammonia, which resulted in the lengthening of the reaction time. Interestingly, the same synthetic sequence was applied on a 35 g scale of 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2 as a one-pot process, which afforded rufinamide in 89% overall yield. Furthermore, the E-factor, which determines the amount of waste generated per kilogram of the product, was 14.6 for the one-step synthetic process, compared with an estimated overall E-factor of 20.2 for the nitrile route.

The final product, rufinamide precursor 11, was obtained in 30 min in 83% yield from the cooling zone after a slow stream of MeOH or MeCN was introduced into the mixing zone of the reactor. The reaction was carried out on a 34 g scale.

In this report, rhombic-dodecahedral Cu2O nanocrystals bounded by {110} facets were shown to be more catalytically active than Cu2O octahedra revealing {111} facets, whereas Cu2O nanocubes displayed the lowest catalytic activity for the multicomponent synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles. For the first time, rufinamide 7 could be synthesized through a multicomponent coupling reaction by employing 2,6-difluorobenzyl bromide 1, NaN3, and propiolamide 12 (Scheme 10). In this multicomponent reaction, Cu2O rhombic dodecahedra (RDs) bounded by {110} facets were selected as the catalysts.
Interestingly, the multicomponent cycloaddition reaction at 55 °C in EtOH as the solvent for 2.5 h afforded rufinamide 7 in 95% yield.

The next year, Jamison and co-workers developed the continuous-flow total synthesis of rufinamide 7 on a 1 M scale using commonly available chemicals. The aim of this study was to develop the continuous-flow technology using benzyl bromide 1 as the primary precursor. Initially, 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2 was obtained in continuous flow via the SN2 substitution reaction of 1 with azide nucleophiles in 1 min using DMSO as the solvent (Scheme 11).

The next step of the reaction involves the continuous-flow synthesis of propiolamide 12, as both 12 and methyl propiolate 10 have a very high tendency to polymerize. Using the optimum conditions, 12 was synthesized by reacting 10 with 4 equiv of NH4OH at 0 °C for 5 min in continuous flow. Mixing the two reaction streams did not cause any solid formation, whereas an increase in the reaction temperature to 140 °C for 6 min gave rufinamide 7 in 10% yield with the formation of 1,5-regioisomers.

2,6-Difluorobenzyl azide 2 again served as the starting material, which underwent the 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction with α,β-unsaturated ester 16 under neat conditions to furnish rufinamide precursor 11 in 85% yield. The 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition reaction was catalyzed by 10 mol % DBU.
The next step of the synthetic sequence involved the ammonolysis of intermediate 11 at room temperature for 24 h to obtain rufinamide 7 in 89% yield.

Starting from 2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 2, within two steps the desired moiety was achieved in 42% overall yield. The methodology based on the reaction of 2 with trichloroacetyl-group-substituted enone 17 as the dipolarophile under neat conditions for 2 days at 135 °C reacted with 2,6-difluoro benzyl azide 2 afforded triazole 18. Then triazole derivative 18 was subjected to a reaction with an aqueous solution of NH4OH, giving rufinamide 7 in 42% yield (Scheme 13).

In an attempt to improve the yield and reduce the number of synthetic steps, a domino process was employed that involved the synthesis of rufinamide 7 directly, without isolation of trichloroacetyl-substituted 1H-1,2,3-triazole 18. After the initial cycloaddition to form 18, a 33% aqueous solution of NH4OH was added to the reaction mixture in the presence of MeOH at room temperature for 30 min to produce rufinamide 7 in 50% yield.

Rufinamide precursor 11 was obtained in 88% isolated yield by reacting 2 with 3-methoxyacrylate 16 via 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition. The uninterrupted continuous-flow process shows chemical and process-design amplification aspects covered by novel process windows where single reaction steps are chemically strengthened via a variety of conditions available in a microreactor environment. Scheme 14 demonstrates the five-stage, three-step continuous-flow synthesis with integrated separation steps resulting in a total yield of 82% based on the amount of 19 used and a productivity of 9 g h–1 for rufinamide precursor 11.
